We developed and evaluated an autonomous clinical artificial intelligence (AI) agent leveraging GPT-4 with multimodal precision oncology tools to support personalized clinical decision-making. The system incorporates vision transformers for detecting microsatellite instability and KRAS and BRAF mutations from histopathology slides, MedSAM for radiological image segmentation and web-based search tools such as OncoKB, PubMed and Google. Evaluated on 20 realistic multimodal patient cases, the AI agent autonomously used appropriate tools with 87.5% accuracy, reached correct clinical conclusions in 91.0% of cases and accurately cited relevant oncology guidelines 75.5% of the time. Compared to GPT-4 alone, the integrated AI agent drastically improved decision-making accuracy from 30.3% to 87.2%. These findings demonstrate that integrating language models with precision oncology and search tools substantially enhances clinical accuracy, establishing a robust foundation for deploying AI-driven personalized oncology support systems.'}, {'paper_id': 3, 'title': 'Strategies for older people living in care homes to prevent urinary tract infection: the StOP UTI realist synthesis', 'abstract': "Background: Urinary tract infection is the most diagnosed infection in older people. It accounts for more than 50% of antibiotic prescriptions in care homes and is a frequent reason for care home residents being hospitalised.\nObjective: This realist review developed and refined programme theories for preventing and recognising urinary tract infection, exploring what works, for whom and in what circumstances.\nDesign: The review used realist synthesis to explore existing literature on the detection and prevention of urinary tract infection, complemented by stakeholder consultation. It applies to the UK context, although other healthcare systems may identify synergies in our findings.\nData sources: Bibliographic databases searched included MEDLINE, CINAHL, EMBASE, Cochrane Library, Web of Science Core Collection (including the Social Sciences Citation Index), Sociological Abstracts, Bibliomap and National Institute for Health and Care Research Journals Library.\nData selection and extraction: Title and abstract screening were undertaken by two researchers independently of each other. Selection and assessment were based on relevance and rigour and cross-checked by a second researcher. Data extracted from the included studies were explored for explanations about how the interventions were considered to work (or not). Evidence tables were constructed to enable identification of patterns across studies that offered insight about the features of successful interventions.\nData analysis and synthesis: Programme theories were constructed through a four-stage process involving scoping workshops, examination of relevant extant theory, analysis and synthesis of primary research, teacher-learner interviews and a cross-system stakeholder event. A process of abductive and retroductive reasoning was used to construct context-mechanism-outcome configurations to inform programme theory.\nResults: The scoping review and stakeholder engagement identified three theory areas that address the prevention and recognition of urinary tract infection and show what is needed to implement best practice. Nine context-mechanism-outcome configurations provided an explanation of how interventions to prevent and recognise urinary tract infection might work in care homes. These were (1) recognition of urinary tract infection is informed by skills in clinical reasoning, (2) decision-support tools enable a whole care team approach to communication, (3) active monitoring is recognised as a legitimate care routine, (4) hydration is recognised as a care priority for all residents, (5) systems are in place to drive action that helps residents to drink more, (6) good infection prevention practice is applied to indwelling urinary catheters, (7) proactive strategies are in place to prevent recurrent urinary tract infection, (8) care home leadership and culture fosters safe fundamental care and (9) developing knowledgeable care teams.\nLimitations: We adapted our approach and work to online interactions with stakeholders and as a research team because of COVID-19. This also had an impact on bringing stakeholders together at a face-to-face event at the end of the project. Studies focusing on the prevention of urinary tract infection in care home settings were predominantly from the USA and Europe where the regulatory and funding systems for the long-term care of the elderly have some differences, particularly in the USA where national reporting plays a significant role in driving improvements in care.\nConclusions: Care home staff have a vital role in the prevention and recognition of urinary tract infection, which can be enabled through integration and prioritisation within the systems and routines of care homes and delivery of person-centred care. Promoting fundamental care as a means of facilitating a holistic approach to prevention and recognition of urinary tract infection helps staff to recognise how they can contribute to antimicrobial stewardship and recognition of sepsis. Challenging assumptions made by staff about the presentation of urinary tract infection is complex and requires education that facilitates 'unlearning' and questioning of low-value practices. Programmes to prevent urinary tract infection need to be co-designed and supported through active and visible leadership by care home managers with support from specialist practitioners.\nFuture work: We will focus on co-designing tools that facilitate implementation of our findings to ensure they fit with the care home context and address some of the challenges faced by care home leaders. This will underpin action at care home and system levels. Further research is needed to better understand the perspectives of residents and family carers, the effectiveness of non-pharmacological, pharmacological and specialist practitioner interventions and non-traditional approaches to training and educating the workforce in care home settings.\nStudy registration: This study is registered as PROSPERO CRD42020201782.\nFunding: This award was funded by the National Institute for Health and Care Research (NIHR) Health Technology Assessment programme (NIHR award ref: NIHR130396) and is published in full in Health Technology Assessment; Vol. 28, No. 68. analysis.title: Landscape Map for Mitigating Hallucination and Misinformation in LLMs for Financial Advisory Systems
analysis.current_research_landscape: The analyzed research cluster primarily centers on optimizing complex decision-making processes in sensitive domains through the use of language models and AI systems, as evidenced by central themes such as 'antibiotic prescribing', 'reducing antimicrobial resistance', and 'optimal treatment'. The core problem being addressed relates to balancing the accuracy and reliability of AI-supported decisions while minimizing erroneous or harmful outputs—hallucinations or misinformation—that could lead to suboptimal or dangerous interventions. The dominant paradigms include combining large language models with domain-specific data and multimodal inputs, program theory frameworks to understand context-mechanism-outcome configurations, and embedding decision-support within routine care settings or clinical workflows. Specifically, research efforts focus on understanding model strengths and limitations, incorporating domain guidelines and evidence citation, and structuring AI-driven support as an augmentation to expert judgment rather than standalone authority. The local thematic islands reflect a dual focus on optimizing treatment strategies (e.g., antibiotic stewardship) and implementation within institutional care environments (e.g., care homes), highlighting the complexity of contextualizing AI output appropriately within healthcare systems.
analysis.critical_gaps: Internal Gaps: The foundational papers underline several limitations including an absence of standardized methodologies to identify and mitigate biases and misinformation in LLM outputs, especially relating to sensitive decision support such as antibiotic prescribing. There is a lack of bridge nodes connecting treatment optimization paradigms with care delivery organizational themes, indicating siloed research with minimal integration of system-wide contextual factors influencing AI adoption and accuracy. Moreover, there is noted difficulty in educating and updating professionals to critically interpret AI outputs, as well as challenges in co-designing tools that fit complex, real-world environments like care homes. External/Novel Gaps: The global analysis reveals a significant hidden bridge between 'optimal treatment' and 'care homes' through health services concepts like home-based screening, social engagement, and care continuity—factors largely unexplored in the local research cluster. Integrating these concepts could help mitigate misinformation in AI for decentralized, home or community-based care financial advisory contexts by factoring patient engagement, behavioral patterns, and adaptive interventions that are sensitive to care utilization dynamics. Such cross-disciplinary insights imply a missed opportunity to contextualize LLM outputs within broader ecosystem factors influencing decision relevance and reliability in non-traditional or less clinically structured environments like financial advisory systems oriented to home care or elderly populations.
analysis.high_potential_innovation_opportunities:
Opportunity 1: Develop integrative AI frameworks combining LLM-based decision support with contextual care system data (e.g., social engagement metrics, home-based service utilization) to reduce hallucination risk by grounding outputs in user-specific, dynamically updated real-world context. This addresses local gaps in contextual embedding and professional education by creating more explainable, user-tailored recommendations.

Opportunity 2: Co-design interactive, continuous-learning AI advisory tools within care home or community financial advisory settings that leverage program theory approaches to model context-mechanism-outcome relationships, enhancing detection and correction of misinformation through stakeholder feedback loops. This links hidden global health services concepts (community-based services, continuity of care) with local methodological limitations in tool implementation.

Opportunity 3: Integrate multimodal precision diagnostics methodologies (e.g., vision transformers, domain-specific knowledge graphs) demonstrated in oncology AI agents with financial advisory LLM systems to validate data-driven insights against external evidence bases. This fusion addresses the internal gap of low citation accuracy and unverified outputs, enhancing trustworthiness in high-stakes financial decision support scenarios relevant to vulnerable populations such as elderly care home residents.
